programme.title: College Football
programme.desc: Kalen DeBoer and his No. 4 Crimson Tide host the Bulls. Kalen DeBoer became the first Alabama coach to win his first game via shutout since Wallace Wade in 1923 with a 63-0 Week 1 rout of Western Kentucky. Alabama defeated South Florida 17-3 in 2023.

programme.title: College Football Final
programme.desc: Once the day's slate of college football games is complete, ESPN recaps the action and discusses its implications on the top 25. Matt Barrie hosts with analysts Joey Galloway and Dan Mullen.

programme.title: College Football
programme.desc: The Sun Devils host the Bulldogs in a meeting of Power Four conference foes. The Jeff Lebby era in Mississippi State began with a 56-7 rout of Eastern Kentucky. Arizona State nearly shut out Wyoming in its opener, but settled for a 48-7 outcome.

programme.desc: The latest news, highlights and inside information from every corner of the sports world is presented each day on "SportsCenter," ESPN's first-ever program when the network debuted in September of 1979. programme.title: College Football Final
programme.desc: Once the day's slate of college football games is complete, ESPN recaps the action and discusses its implications on the top 25. Matt Barrie hosts with analysts Joey Galloway and Dan Mullen.

programme.title: NFL Matchup
programme.desc: An NFL Films production, "NFL Matchup" is definitely a show for football junkies. Unlike traditional football preview programs, this one gives fans an in-depth look at some of Sunday's games by breaking down the strategy and tactics -- the Xs and Os -- through the exclusive use of team-supplied footage. That type of film study is a forte of former NFL player and executive Louis Riddick and NFL Films producer Greg Cosell, whose work is featured here alongside host Sal Paolantonio.

programme.title: Sunday NFL Countdown
programme.desc: This Sunday pregame staple debuted in 1985 and soon became a signature ESPN series. Host Samantha Ponder introduces the features and directs the storylines associated with the day's games, joined by a roster of analysts highlighted by ex-NFL players, coaches and executives including Tedy Bruschi, Randy Moss, Matt Hasselbeck, Rex Ryan and Louis Riddick. Chris Mortensen and Adam Schefter deliver breaking news and injury updates, while reporters at game sites set the scenes.

programme.title: NWSL Soccer
programme.desc: The Dash (3-10-5) face a stiff test as they head to New Jersey to face Gotham FC (10-4-4). Gotham, licking their wounds after a 2-0 loss to league-leading Orlando on Sept. 1, defeated Houston 1-0 on May 8 thanks to an early Lynn Williams goal.

programme.title: Fútbol W
programme.desc: Ali Krieger and Sebastian Salazar host a weekly studio program featuring comprehensive coverage of professional women's soccer.

programme.title: WNBA Countdown
programme.desc: WNBA news, analysis, highlights and interviews.

programme.title: WNBA Basketball
programme.desc: The Aces continue a challenging trip by playing the first-place Liberty. New York has won both meetings this season after losing to Las Vegas in the 2023 WNBA Finals. The Aces conclude their journey with two games against Caitlin Clark and the Fever.

programme.title: Baseball Tonight: Sunday Night Countdown
programme.desc: Leading into each of ESPN's Sunday Night Baseball telecasts is this special edition of "Baseball Tonight." Host Karl Ravech teams with analysts and reporters to present fans a detailed preview of the network's exclusive, national game of the week. Highlights of the day's other games, interviews with players and managers, and key storylines from around the league also fill the hourlong show. Mark Teixeira, Eduardo Pérez, Tim Kurkjian and Buster Olney are among the analysts.

programme.title: MLB Baseball
programme.desc: Houston's Justin Verlander tries to rediscover his form in a game against Arizona. The 41-year-old has lost all three starts since returning from the injured list. Arizona counters with Ryne Nelson, 5-0 in 12 outings since his last loss on June 26.

programme.title: SportsCenter
programme.desc: The latest news, highlights and inside information from every corner of the sports world is presented each day on "SportsCenter," ESPN's first-ever program when the network debuted in September of 1979. The flagship series airs an evening edition and a brand new midnight show each weekday before the stage is cleared for a live "SportsCenter" morning block that emphasizes fast-paced, highlights-driven reports and what's new on social media platforms.

programme.title: SportsCenter With Scott Van Pelt
programme.desc: SVP's up at midnight and bringing his unique perspective on games people play to "SportsCenter" viewers. The hourlong, late-night show is driven by the host's self-deprecating wit and passion for sports, with featured elements, including Van Pelt's nightly "1 Big Thing" commentary and a weekly look back at the moments that drove bettors wild in "Bad Beats." The show also delivers what "SportsCenter" fans are used to -- news and highlights, guests and interviews -- but in a different, fast-paced and insightful way.

programme.title: Get Up
programme.desc: ESPN's morning show features host Mike Greenberg with a rotating and diverse group of analysts opining about and analyzing the latest news from the world of sports. The two-hour, personality-driven show originates from Manhattan's South Street Seaport, a locale that attracts high-profile guests. Greenberg, aka "Greeny," is formerly one-half of ESPN Radio's longtime "Mike & Mike" morning show.

programme.title: First Take
programme.desc: Stephen A. Smith joins host Molly Qerim on this weekday morning sports debate show. Smith provides his expert takes on the day's trending sports topics and under-the-radar news. They're regularly joined by veteran analysts and the top guests in sports and entertainment.

programme.title: The Pat McAfee Show
programme.desc: Former NFL punter Pat McAfee brings his humor and candor to the microphone to highlight the day's top stories.

programme.title: SportsCenter
programme.desc: The latest news, highlights and inside information from every corner of the sports world is presented each day on "SportsCenter," ESPN's first-ever program when the network debuted in September of 1979. The flagship series airs an evening edition and a brand new midnight show each weekday before the stage is cleared for a live "SportsCenter" morning block that emphasizes fast-paced, highlights-driven reports and what's new on social media platforms.

programme.title: NFL Live
programme.desc: Host Laura Rutledge takes the helm of this weekday show featuring the likes of Marcus Spears, Dan Orlovsky, Mina Kimes, and Adam Schefter. The "NFL Live" crew entertains fans while offering all the latest news and analysis from across the NFL.

programme.title: Around the Horn
programme.desc: Hosted by Tony Reali in the ESPN studio and joined via satellite by four panelists from across the country, the team debates popular sports stories. Reali acts as moderator, giving points for well-made arguments and deducting points for those who inspire him to hit the "mute" button. At the end of the show, whomever Reali deems the winner has 30 seconds without interruption to voice their final opinions on any topic they want.

programme.title: Pardon the Interruption
programme.desc: The debate is the story in this fast-paced, half-hour series hosted by former Washington Post sportswriters Tony Kornheiser and Michael Wilbon. The pair engage in high-energy discussions, conduct interviews and often argue over topics not even related to sports. Other sports reporters appear as guests and offer opinions on the top stories of the day.

programme.title: Monday Night Countdown
programme.desc: Previewing the Monday Night Football matchup airing later on ESPN. Host Scott Van Pelt is joined by Ryan Clark, Robert Griffin III, Marcus Spears, Adam Schefter and Michelle Beisner-Buck as they analyze every last morsel of information pertaining to Monday night's combatants, plus discuss the latest news that developed out of Sunday's action.

programme.title: NFL Football
programme.desc: Aaron Rodgers returns as his Jets visit the 49ers. Rodgers sustained an Achilles tendon injury in Week 1 last season on his fourth snap under center with New York. San Francisco comes off a 25-22 overtime loss to Kansas City in the 2024 Super Bowl.

programme.title: Monday Night Postgame
programme.desc: A recap of the Monday Night Football matchup with highlights, interviews and more.

Providing the latest info are host Field Yates, analysts Mike Clay and Damien Woody, and senior writer and injury analyst Stephania Bell. Also contributing to the show are ESPN's NFL reporters, who bring fantasy players the latest intel from game sites and, in many cases, straight from the coach's mouth to give fantasy owners everything they need to know to set their lineups.

The pair engage in high-energy discussions, conduct interviews and often argue over topics not even related to sports. Other sports reporters appear as guests and offer opinions on the top stories of the day.

programme.title: SportsCenter
programme.desc: The latest news, highlights and inside information from every corner of the sports world is presented each day on "SportsCenter," ESPN's first-ever program when the network debuted in September of 1979. The flagship series airs an evening edition and a brand new midnight show each weekday before the stage is cleared for a live "SportsCenter" morning block that emphasizes fast-paced, highlights-driven reports and what's new on social media platforms.

Greenberg, aka "Greeny," is formerly one-half of ESPN Radio's longtime "Mike & Mike" morning show.

programme.desc: Hosted by Tony Reali in the ESPN studio and joined via satellite by four panelists from across the country, the team debates popular sports stories. At the end of the show, whomever Reali deems the winner has 30 seconds without interruption to voice their final opinions on any topic they want.

programme.desc: Jamal Murray scored 35 points, Nikola Jokic had 34 and the Nuggets held on to hand the Celtics their first home loss of the season. Jayson Tatum had a chance to tie at the end, but he missed a one-legged fadeaway off the rim. From Jan. 19, 2024.

programme.title: NBA TV Marquee Matchup
programme.desc: Nikola Jokic finished with 25 points, 16 rebounds and 12 assists to spoil the Milwaukee coaching debut of Doc Rivers by recording his 14th triple-double of the season as the Denver Nuggets surged by the Bucks, 113-107. From Jan. 29, 2024.

programme.title: NBA TV Marquee Matchup
programme.desc: Jamal Murray scored 29 points, Michael Porter Jr. added 27 and the Nuggets snapped the Los Angeles Lakers' three-game winning streak with a 114-106 victory. Anthony Davis scored 32 points and LeBron James had 25 for the Lakers. From Feb. 8, 2024.

programme.title: NBA TV Marquee Matchup
programme.desc: LeBron James became the first player in NBA history to score 40,000 career points as the Los Angeles Lakers All-Star officially crossed the threshold in a 124-114 loss to the Denver Nuggets. From March 2, 2024.

programme.title: NBA TV Marquee Matchup
programme.desc: Nikola Jokic had 32 points, 12 rebounds and 11 assists, recording his 20th triple-double of the season as the Denver Nuggets withstood a furious fourth-quarter surge by Boston to beat the Celtics, 115-109. From March 7, 2024.

programme.title: NBA TV Marquee Matchup
programme.desc: From March 15, 2024.

programme.title: NBA TV Marquee Matchup
programme.desc: Nikola Jokic had 35 points and 16 rebounds and Michael Porter Jr. scored 13 of his 26 points in the fourth quarter as the Denver Nuggets fended off the undermanned and undersized Minnesota Timberwolves, 115-112. From March 19, 2024.

programme.title: NBA TV Marquee Matchup
programme.desc: James Harden hit a tie-breaking 3-pointer to send the Los Angeles Clippers to their first victory since his arrival, snapping their six-game losing streak with a 106-100 win over the Houston Rockets in the NBA In-Season Tournament. Nov. 17, 2023.

programme.title: NBA TV Marquee Matchup
programme.desc: Kawhi Leonard had 34 points and seven assists, James Harden scored 26 and the Los Angeles Clippers overcame a big game by De'Aaron Fox (40 points) to beat the Sacramento Kings, 131-117. From Nov. 29, 2023.

programme.title: NBA TV Marquee Matchup
programme.desc: Kawhi Leonard scored 14 of his 21 points in the final five minutes and the Clippers overcame an 18-point deficit with a game-ending 22-0 run to beat the Brooklyn Nets, 125-114. From Jan. 21, 2024.

programme.title: NBA TV Marquee Matchup
programme.desc: Kawhi Leonard scored 36 points, including 11 in the fourth quarter, and the Clippers finished off a long road trip with a 149-144 win over the Hawks. James Harden added 30 points and 10 assists while Trae Young had 25 points. From Feb. 5, 2024.

programme.title: NBA TV Marquee Matchup
programme.desc: Norman Powell made four 3-pointers over the final 7:03 to score 21 points and outduel Stephen Curry down the stretch, and the Clippers rallied from 12 down in the fourth quarter to beat the Warriors, 130-125. From Feb. 14, 2024.

programme.title: NBA TV Marquee Matchup
programme.desc: Kawhi Leonard had 28 points, and Paul George and James Harden each scored 21 as the Los Angeles Clippers rallied for a 122-116 win over the Houston Rockets. From March 6, 2024.
